Graphical abstract Molybdenum trioxide (MoO3) nanoparticles with an average size below 100nm were prepared by solvothermal synthesis of nano-crystalline molybdenum dioxide (MoO2) and subsequent thermal oxidative annealing. The successful preparation of this type of nanoparticles was confirmed by evidence obtained from characterization by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analysis and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR). The MoO3 nanoparticles were tested as catalytic precursor in the epoxidation of cis-cyclooctene, styrene, R-(+)-limonene and trans-hex-2-en-1-ol, using tert-butylhydroperoxide (tbhp) as oxygen source under different reaction conditions, namely, various solvents and temperatures. The catalytic studies show that the MoO3 nanoparticles perform selective epoxidation of the tested substrates with very high yield, especially at high temperature and using toluene as solvent. Furthermore, the catalyst remains active across several reaction cycles with virtually no loss of activity. Keywords Metal oxide Molybdenum Nanoparticle Oxidation catalysis Recyclability 1 Introduction Nanoscience has evolved into a major research field of Modern Society, during the XXth century, as a result of a continuing effort to miniaturize to the nanoscale size processes that occur so far at the microscale level. In order to achieve this objective, it is generally accepted that bottom-up approaches should replace the classic top-down. Metal and metal oxide-containing nanostructures with different morphologies (nanowires, nanobelts, nanofibres etc.) are known to exhibit better adjustable properties in fields such as gas sensors, electrodes or optoelectronics than their conventional counterparts [1]. In this context, MoO3 nanoparticles have attracted a great deal of attention due to their unique physical and chemical properties that differ from those in the bulk, in particular for their high surface-to-volume ratio, exceptionally high for nanoparticles with an approximate diameter between 1 and 100nm [2]. The development of MoO3 nanoparticles has consequently increased in recent years, because these nanoparticles can play a critical role in many industrial applications. MoO3 nanoparticles present two structural phases: the thermodynamically stable orthorhombic α-phase and the metastable monoclinic β-phase [3]. Orthorhombic α-MoO3 nanoparticles are promising oxides with structural anisotropy and a wide n-type bandgap, which is very attractive for technological applications such as photodegradation [4], degradation of dyes [5], gas sensor [6], electrodes for batteries [7] and catalysis [8]. Orthorhombic α-MoO3 possesses an anisotropic layered crystal structure that is composed of bilayers of distorted MoO6 octahedra along the (010) direction of the Pbnm space group setting. The interlayer interaction is mainly through van der Waals forces [9]. The monoclinic β-phase, although believed to be superior to the α-phase in catalysis [10] and electrochemical applications [11], has been quite difficult to produce in single phase [12]. Recently a microplasma method has openend the way to produce single-phase nanosheets of the β-phase for applications in Li-ion batteries [13]. Various MoO3 nanostructures in the α-phase, including nanowires [14], nanotubes [5], nanobelts [4] and nanofibers [15] were fabricated by different methods, the most popular being the hydrothermal synthesis. The hydrothermal method is simple and cost effective. It is a low temperature process which yields various nanostructures with controlled size, stoichiometry and shape [6]. Another important feature of molybdenum trioxide is the versatility of its catalytic properties in a different type of reactions, such as epoxidation catalysis. To this respect the use of such metal oxide materials in oxidation catalysis was pioneered by Volta in the late 1970's [16,17]. These studies aimed at correlating selective oxidation processes with the structural properties of the catalysts. For instance, in some of his works, Volta established that MoO3 can yield products selectively, depending on the crystal face where the reaction occurs. For instance, propene oxidation can occur at the (100) face yielding acrolein, whereas it can also yield CO2 if the reaction occurs at the (010) face [18]. Olefin epoxidation is a major field of research in the preparation of relevant building blocks for organic synthesis as fine chemicals as well as pharmaceuticals and agrochemicals [19–21]. Among other metal systems, Mo-catalyzed olefin epoxidation has received interest from both academic and industrial research laboratories [22,23]. Since the first example of a molybdenum oxo complex catalyzing the epoxidation of alkenes with peroxides such as organic hydroperoxides and hydrogen peroxide [24], a variety of different systems has been developed [25,26]. Inclusively, in recent times, many efficient epoxidation Mo-based catalysts are based on Mo organometallic complexes which work as precatalysts [26]. Our group has performed intensive research on olefin epoxidation [27–29], and as a continuation of those studies, we describe in the present work the preparation and subsequent evaluation of the catalytic potential of α-MoO3 nanoparticles in the epoxidation of olefins, under different reaction conditions. 2 Experimental 2.1 General All reagents were obtained from Aldrich and used as received. Commercial grade solvents were dried and deoxygenated by standard procedures distilled under nitrogen, and kept over 4Å molecular sieves. Fourier transform infrared spectra (FTIR) were obtained as KBr pellets on a Nicolet 6700 in the 400–4000cm−1 range using 2cm−1 resolution. Powder X-ray diffraction measurements were taken on a Philips Analytical PW 3050/60 X’Pert PRO equipped with X’Celerator detector and with automatic data acquisition in theta/2theta mode (X’Pert Data Collector (v2.0b) software), using Cu Kα radiation (40kV; 30mA). Profile fitting on the data was performed with the FullProf suite of programs [30]. The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were obtained on a FEG-SEM (Field Emission Gun Scanning Electron Microscope) from JEOL, model JSM-7001F. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were obtained on a Hitachi microscope, model H-8100 with a LaB6 filament and using an acceleration tension of 200kV in Microlab, Instituto Superior Técnico. MoO3 Nanoparticles were prepared according to a method described in the literature [6]. MoO3 nanoparticles were prepared using 0.325g of commercial MoCl5 that was fully dissolved in 40mL of distilled water and 10mL of ethanol. After stirring for 1h, the prepared solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, kept at 453K overnight and then air-cooled to room temperature. The resulting precipitate was centrifuged, washed with distilled water and ethanol several times, and oven-dried at 353K. Subsequent annealing at 723K for 1h transformed the precipitate into alpha-MoO3 nanoparticles. 2.2 Catalytic tests The molybdenum nanoparticles were tested in the catalytic epoxidation of cis-cyclooctene, styrene, trans-hex-2-en-1-ol and R(+)-limonene, using tert-butylhydroperoxide (tbhp) as oxidant (5.5M in n-decane). The catalytic tests were carried out at 353, 383 and 393K using respectively acetonitrile, toluene and decane as solvents. The reactions occurred under normal atmospheric conditions in a reaction vessel equipped with a magnetic stirrer and a condenser. In a typical experiment the vessel was loaded with the olefin or the alcohol (100%), internal standard (dibutylether, DBE), catalyst (1%), oxidant (200%) and 3mL of solvent (acetonitrile, toluene or decane). The final volume of the reaction is ca. 6mL. The addition of the oxidant determines the beginning of the reaction. Conversion, product yields and selectivity were monitored by sampling periodically and analyzing them using a Shimadzu QP2100-Plus GC/MS system and a capillary column (Teknokroma TRB-5MS/TRB-1MS) operating in the linear velocity mode. 2.3 Leaching and recycling tests In general, recycling experiments were carried out as described in the previous section; after each cycle (24h) the catalyst was washed with dichloromethane (CH2Cl2) several times and dried prior to reuse in a new catalytic cycle [31]. These experiments were performed to assess the robustness of the catalyst. For the leaching experiments after 2h reaction, the catalyst was filtered off, and the reactions continued under the same conditions. Alternatively, similar experiments were carried out using a centrifuging step rather than filtration for separating the catalyst. These experiments were conducted to assess whether the catalyst was leaching into the liquid phase during catalysis. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of nanoparticles Molybdenum oxide nanoparticles (MoO3) were synthesized by solvothermal synthesis of nano-crystalline MoO2, using commercial MoCl5 in the presence of a mixture of water and ethanol, and subsequent thermal oxidative annealing as described by Kim et al. [6]. The nanoparticles were characterized by X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns of the reaction products were recorded both after the solvothermal synthesis and the oxidative annealing, in order to confirm the two-step process having MoO2 as intermediate state of the production of MoO3 nanoparticles (Fig. 1 ). In Fig. 1 the top diffraction pattern is from the precipitate after the solvothermal synthesis, exhibiting the peaks characteristic of MoO2 in the monoclinic P21/c phase. Indexing and line intensities appear compatible with both the JCPDS cards 86-0315 and 78-1073 while a LeBail profile fitting has given refined cell parameters of: a =5.6235(12), b =4.8483(15), c =5.6262(8), β =120.62(1), in reasonable agreement with values reported from a Rietveld refinement on neutron powder diffraction data [32]. The bottom pattern in Fig. 1 is the diffraction pattern of the precipitate after the thermal oxidative annealing step. The diffraction peaks are those characteristic of the orthorhombic α-MoO3 phase when compared to JCPDS card 05-0508 [33]. The lattice parameters (Å) obtained by a LeBail profile fitting in the orthorhombic space group Pbnm [34] are: a =3.9557(6), b =13.867(2) and c =3.6965(4), in agreement with a recent X-rays single-crystal determination [35,36]. The calcined MoO3 nanoparticles were further investigated by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The SEM images exhibit somewhat aggregated particles with hexagonal/circular shape and with two smooth faces (Fig. 2a and b). The TEM image (Fig. 2c) confirms SEM observations by displaying nanoparticles with some aggregation. Concerning particle size, a size distribution is visually identified in the image, and it is possible to infer that the average dimension is below 100nm. FTIR spectrum was performed to investigate chemical bonding states between molybdenum and oxygen atoms. The spectrum shown in Fig. 3 , displays several bands that can be assigned to, the surface adsorbed water; in particular, the νOH mode is found at 3443cm−1 while the δ(H2O) deformation mode of is detected at 1629cm−1. The νMoOH vibrational mode appears at 1400cm−1, and was associated to the interaction of the Mo with some water in the surface. Bands arising from the Mo vibrations appear at 995, 865 and 615cm−1, being assigned to the vibrations of νMoO, the νMoOMo vibrations of MoVI and to the δ(MoOMo) mode. These data agree with previous literature reported values [4], and thus confirms successful synthesis of the MoO3 nanoparticles. 3.2 Catalytic studies The MoO3 nanoparticles were tested as catalyst precursor for the epoxidation of two sets of substrates. The former comprises simple olefins, such as cis-cyclooctene and styrene, while the latter includes multifunctional olefins, namely, trans-hex-2-en-1-ol and R-(+)-limonene. All reactions were carried out using tert-butylhydroperoxide (tbhp) as oxygen donor, in different solvents, namely, acetonitrile, toluene and decane, and at different temperatures, i.e. 353, 383 and 393K. In the reaction with cis-cyclooctene, MoO3 nanoparticles catalyzed selectively the oxidation of substrate to the corresponding epoxide, without formation of any by-products (Table 1 , entries 1–4). Although all the reactions converted cis-cyclooctene yielding exclusively the corresponding epoxide (100% selectivity), the most striking result emerged when using a higher temperature (393K) combined with decane as solvent. In this case it was possible to totally convert the substrate in a time as short as 1h of reaction (Table 1, entry 4), giving an 8-fold increase in the velocity of the reaction. It was also important to evaluate how both solvent and temperature parameters influenced catalyst performance. Fig. 4a presents the kinetics of formation of cis-cyclooctene epoxide. It is possible to verify that at the same temperature (353K) the choice of the solvent influences the catalyst performance. In particular, acetonitrile (filled squares) yields better kinetics than toluene (filled circles). It is also important to note that when toluene was used at 383K (open squares) the kinetics roughly matched the one obtained for acetonitrile at 353K. For this particular system it is clear that acetonitrile is a good choice as it is more efficient at the lowest temperature tested than toluene. On the other hand, when the temperature is further increased (393K) and using decane (Fig. 4a, open circles) the reaction kinetics is boosted reaching 100% substrate conversion with concomitant complete selectivity just after 1h of reaction, which is remarkable. In this case, however, one cannot distinguish whether such boost is a result of solvent, temperature or both combined effects. Styrene conversion is very efficient for all tested conditions reaching almost 100% of conversion (Table 1, entries 5–8). Although epoxide selectivity is low in all cases (especially at 393K, Table 1, entry 8), the major product obtained is benzaldehyde. This product is obtained with excellent selectivity meaning that MoO3 is most adequate to perform two-electron oxidation reactions on this substrate. Benzaldehyde selectivity was found to increase concomitantly with temperature (Table 1, entries 5–8). R-(+)-limonene is a substrate with two unsaturated CC bonds; in this way two different epoxides, the endo- and exocyclic isomers, are feasible. In the present work, it was possible to convert the substrate with high conversion rates across all catalytic tests (Table 1, entries 9–12) and the endocyclic epoxide was the only isomer obtained in all the catalytic tests performed. Product selectivity was found to range between 90% and 98% tested at both 353 and 383K across all conditions (Table 1, entries 9–11). The most interesting feature is that in these systems the E-isomer was the one formed preferentially. Despite this, when changing the solvent to decane and using a higher temperature (393K) a detrimental effect in the performance of the catalytic system was observed. In this case, although limonene conversion and epoxide selectivity are still very high, the selectivity toward the epoxide E-isomer drops (Table 1, entry 12), yielding the epoxide Z-isomer as the by-product (34% yield). The epoxidation reaction using decane as solvent was repeated at 353 and 413K. Results showed that under these conditions, epoxide Z-isomer yield changes concomitantly with temperature increase, as evidenced in Fig. 4b, reaching 45% yield at the highest temperature. In what concerns the oxidation of trans-hex-2-en-1-ol it was possible to obtain excellent results regarding conversion of substrate (Table 1, entries 13–16). Conversions were around 100% after 4h of reaction at 353K in toluene (Table 1, entry 14) and after 2h of reaction at 383K in toluene or at 393K in decane (Table 1, entries 15 and 16). Selectivity for epoxide was also quite good (between 95% and 100%) across all the tested conditions. Kinetics of trans-hex-2-en-1-ol epoxide yield, Fig. 4c, showed that when toluene was used as solvent (blue open squares) it is faster than for the other tested solvents. Concerning temperature, catalyst performance was better for the intermediate temperature (383K) (blue line) opposite to what happened for cis-cyclooctene. Solvent effects are known to be very important but not easy to be understood as this is substrate dependent [37]. In this work, strong effects were observed in the epoxidation of styrene and R-(+)-limonene. In the case of R-(+)-limonene the solvent effect was strong when using decane, where the ratio between diastereomers of limonene oxide changes across a temperature range. The same effect was observed in the case of styrene, as a function of both temperature and solvent. In this case, although benzaldehyde was always the major product, the use of apolar solvents seems to promote this product by a great amount, being almost the sole product (Table 1, entry 8). Reusability of the catalyst was also evaluated, since robustness is a very important feature for a catalyst allowing it to be used in several consecutive cycles. Tests in toluene at 383K revealed that MoO3 nanoparticles kept their catalytic activity constant and very high (around 100%) even after four cycles in most cases (Fig. 5 ). Although for styrene epoxidation the major product was not the epoxide as already mentioned before. Concerning selectivity, with exception of styrene epoxidation, all other substrates were selectively converted to the corresponding epoxides with excellent selectivity across all cycles. Cis-cyclooctene oxide was achieved always with 100% selectivity, while R-(+)-limonene and trans-hex-2-en-1-ol epoxides selectivity ranged between 91% and 98% for the former and between 94% and 100% for the latter. In order to assess the true nanometric nature of the catalyst, its stability toward leaching was also evaluated. Leaching experiments for the epoxidation of cis-cyclooctene catalyzed by the MoO3 nanoparticles were carried out in toluene at 353K. The catalyst was filtered off after 2h reaction time (at which substrate conversion was ca. 50%); the reaction in the remaining solution was monitored up to 24h and the final conversion was found to be near 100%. This means that the catalyst is not heterogeneous in nature showing that the nanoparticles have a size distribution (as confirmed by TEM images, Fig. 2c) and the smaller ones are not retained by the filtration step. In a second leaching experiment, the procedure was slightly changed. At 2h the reaction slurry was centrifuged to separate the solid. Then the solution was monitored again till 24h as in the previous leaching experiment. According to Fig. 6 , the centrifugation step was found to be efficient at separating the catalyst. In this case the reaction did not proceed further as in the previous leaching experiment. 3.3 Comparison with literature data The catalytic performance achieved by these MoO3 nanoparticles was so impressive that a comparison with other systems reported in the literature was inevitable. Table 2 collects data from catalytic olefin epoxidation experiments tested across several materials, based on a literature survey, for a set of olefins including cis-cyclooctene, styrene, R-(+)-limonene and trans-hex-2-en-1-ol. The catalysts surveyed cover a wide selection, ranging from nanoparticles to micro/mesoporous materials. As can be seen from data presented in Table 2, in general terms all catalysts showed high activity and good selectivity for epoxides in the transformations considered. Selectivity to the corresponding epoxide products can sometimes be an issue in the systems presented. For instance, Přech reported a Ti-pillared TS1 material that was inefficient in cyclooctene epoxidation [40]. That material reached only 19% conversion and epoxide selectivity was as low as 80%. By the same token the MoO3 catalyst reported in this work suffer from the same problem in the epoxidation of styrene (Table 2, entry 12). For this substrate, the best performing catalysts were those based on Ag nanoparticles immobilized on maghemite and Au nanoparticles immobilized on TS1 material (Table 2, entries 8 and 14). Both systems reached high substrate conversion above 90% with epoxide selectivity of 90% in both cases. In the case of R-(+)-limonene and trans-hex-2-en-1-ol epoxidation, the best performing catalyst was found to be the MoO3 nanoparticles reported in this work. In fact, for R-(+)-limonene, the use of TS1 material as catalyst, reported by Wróblewska, showed to be either completely inactive or unselective, depending on the reaction conditions (Table 2, entries 18 and 19). 4 Conclusions In this work we report the successful preparation of α-MoO3 nanoparticles with an average size below 100nm by solvothermal synthesis of MoO2 nano-crystalline particles and subsequent thermal oxidative annealing. Preparation of α-MoO3 nanoparticles was confirmed by evidence obtained from characterization by powder XRD, SEM/TEM analysis, as well as from data of FTIR spectroscopy. The MoO3 nanoparticles were used as catalysts and revealed to be very active in olefin epoxidation of a variety of olefins using tert-butylhydroperoxide (tbhp) as oxygen source. Results of catalytic tests show that the catalyst conducts selectively to the desired epoxides, with the exception of styrene which yields benzaldehyde. In this particular case, benzaldehyde was found to be obtained with increasing selectivity as the temperature of the reaction increases. The best value was achieved at 393K with 95% selectivity for bezaldehyde. The catalyst performance was quite good under a wide temperature range and with different solvents, especially for higher temperatures and with acetonitrile or toluene as solvents. The catalyst also showed to be very active over recycling experiments without activity loss after four cycles. Comparison with literature data on related systems evidences that the present catalyst levels or outperforms its counterparts across several points: excellent substrate conversion and product selectivity and kinetic rate acceleration. In addition, this catalyst is prepared by a simple synthesis procedure which makes it a clear advantage over others used in the same epoxidation reactions. Based on these results, further studies are being conducted to test this catalyst under aqueous conditions, a much greener media, which will deliver enhanced applications. coredata.dc:description: Molybdenum trioxide (MoO3) nanoparticles with an average size below 100nm were prepared by solvothermal synthesis of nano-crystalline molybdenum dioxide (MoO2) and subsequent thermal oxidative annealing. The successful preparation of this type of nanoparticles was confirmed by evidence obtained from characterization by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analysis and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR). The MoO3 nanoparticles were tested as catalytic precursor in the epoxidation of cis-cyclooctene, styrene, R-(+)-limonene and trans-hex-2-en-1-ol, using tert-butylhydroperoxide (tbhp) as oxygen source under different reaction conditions, namely, various solvents and temperatures. The catalytic studies show that the MoO3 nanoparticles perform selective epoxidation of the tested substrates with very high yield, especially at high temperature and using toluene as solvent. Furthermore, the catalyst remains active across several reaction cycles with virtually no loss of activity.
coredata.dc:title: Highly selective and recyclable MoO3 nanoparticles in epoxidation catalysis
